"that is suitable for honoring God"

tn.ref: before all the ages of time
tn.text: "before time began"
"At the proper time"
Paul speaks of God's message as if it were an object that could be visibly shown to people. AT: "He proclaimed his word" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"I was entrusted to proclaim" or "he gave me the responsibility to preach"
"God, who saves us"

Though Titus was not Paul's biological son, they share a common faith in Christ. Thus, in Christ, Paul considers Titus as his own son. AT: "you are like a son to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul expresses the same faith in Christ that they both share. AT: "the same teachings that we both believe in"
This was a common greeting Paul uses. AT: "may you experience kindness and peace within"
"Christ Jesus who is our savior"
"This is the reason"
"I told you to stay in Crete"

tn.ref: that you might set in order things not yet complete
tn.text: "so that you would finish arranging things that needed to done"
"appoint elders" (UDB) or "designate elders"
In the early Christian churches, Christian elders gave spiritual leadership to the assemblies of believers.
Having told Titus to ordain elders in every city on the island of Crete, Paul gives the requirements for elders.

tn.ref: An elder must be without blame
tn.text: To be "without blame" is to be known as a person who does not do bad things. AT: "An elder must not have a bad reputation."
to be a faithful husband. Possible meanings are 1) does not pursue relationships with other women or 2) does not have a second wife or concubine.
Possible meanings are 1) children who believe in Jesus or 2) children who are trustworthy.
"rebellious" or "who do not follow rules"
Paul speaks of elders as if they were the heads of families, in charge of households. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"not an alcoholic" or "does not drink much wine"
"not one who is violent" or "not one who likes to fight" (UDB)
Paul is changing his argument from what an elder is not to be to what an elder is to be.

tn.ref: a friend of what is good
tn.text: To embrace good things and good behavior.
Paul speaks of devotion to the Christian faith as if it were grasping the faith with one's hands. AT: "be devoted to" or "know well"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
He must teach what is true about God and other spiritual matters.
Because of those that would oppose God's word, Paul gives Titus reasons to preach the God's word and warns him about false teachers.
These are rebellious people opposing Paul's gospel message.
This refers to the Christian Jews who taught that one must be circumcised to follow Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Their words do not benefit anyone"

tn.ref: It is necessary to stop them
tn.text: "They must be prevented from spreading their teachings" or "They must be stopped from influencing others by their words"
Things that are not proper to teach regarding Christ and the Law.
This refers only to profit that people make by doing things that are not honorable.
"destroy the faith of whole families"
"One of the Cretans" or "Someone from the people of Crete"
Possible meanings are 1) a prophet or 2) a poet or philosopher or 3) a teacher.
"Cretans lie all the time." This is an exaggeration for many cretans habitually lie. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This metaphor compares the Cretans to dangerous beasts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
an idiom for people who do nothing but eat too much food. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"therefore tell them strongly that they are wrong"

tn.ref: that they may be sound in the faith
tn.text: "so they will have a healthy faith" or "so their faith may be true"
Paul continues his instructions for what Titus is to teach the Cretans.
This refers to the false teaching of the Jews.
Paul speaks of the truth as if it were an object in motion that could be turned back in the direction from where it came. AT: "reject the truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: To those who are pure, all things are pure
tn.text: "If someone is pure inside, everything they do will be pure."
"To those who are acceptable to God"

tn.ref: to those who are stained and unbelieving, nothing is pure
tn.text: Paul speaks of sinners as if they were physically dirty. AT: "the one who is morally defiled and who does not believe cannot be pure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: they deny him by their deeds
tn.text: "their actions prove that they do not know him"
"disgusting"

tn.ref: They are unapproved for any good deed
tn.text: "no one expects them to do anything good"
